utterances: So this is a C and C laser cutting machine, and it actually uses a laser, light beam to cut through steel.
Back at the Metal Works factory, you can get a sense of the long and tenuous road ahead from Fred Pierce.
Well, I mean, you've got to remember that Iran is a different case because they're Shiite.
The Dawa Party is Islamist-Shiite Party.
They have some things in common.
Everybody else are Sunni Arabs, and they're terrified of sort of Shiite hegemony in Iraq.
Countries like Jordan and Saudi Arabia - probably are two of our three most closest allies in the region - are very uncomfortable with him.
And they're very uncomfortable with the overall Shiite ascendancy in the country.
But it doesn't have to do with his personality or him in particular.
It's the sect he comes from and who he represents.
Yeah.
I mean, yeah.
If they have doubts, it's the political party and the things he believes.
It's not a question of his personal style.
One of the arguments put forth recently by American officials seem to reflect an anger or frustration at Iraqis themselves.
Here's Trent Lott, senator, on FOX News Sunday.
And he's talking about Prime Minister Nouri al-Maliki.
(Soundbite of FOX News interview)
I think we're going to have to be very aggressive and specific with him.
And if he doesn't show real leadership, doesn't try to bring the situation under control - if in fact he becomes a part of the problem, we're going to have to make some tough decisions.
Senator Trent Lott there, saying that the Iraqis will have to decide what they want to do.
Donald Rumsfeld says they have to pull up their socks.
What's behind this criticism?
It's just astonishing.
I mean, this whole pulling up their socks argument implies that, as a matter of fact, Iraqis do prefer to live amidst chaos and bloodshed, or that they are lazy or incompetent.
And certainly, we share none of the blame for what's gone wrong there.
It's just astonishing to me.

This fundamental misunderstanding that comments like Senator Lott's imply - that he and people like him have - is that what's going in Iraq is not people being lazy or wanting to live in death and misery.
It's the fact that you have a very sectarian country, where two groups - predominantly the Shiite Arabs and the Sunni Arabs - are playing a winner takes all game for power.
They're not interested in compromise.
They're not interested in going up.
They're working very, very hard to kill each other and defeat each other.

Now, while I agree it would be nice to see them decide that compromise and peace are better, to imply that somehow they're just childish and unwilling to live in peace and that's why there's a problem there, it reflects a profound ignorance, I guess, of Iraqi history.
Donald Rumsfeld has also used an analogy of a parent teaching a child to ride a bike.
He says we have to take the hand off the bicycle seat.
He said that in his leaked memo, and it's quoted in Bob Woodward's recent book, too.
Is there anything about that analogy you find apt?
Well, no. I mean, this thing about Rumsfeld's memo - it's essentially a blueprint for defeat as the administration has been defining it for three years now - basically, pull back and give up.

I mean, if you think that Iraq is sort of some ally being stabilized by the steadying hand of America on the bicycle seat - if you believe that, as former Defense Secretary Rumsfeld seems to believe, then you can imagine what it would be like if you took the hand off the seat.

And taking the hand off the seat in that situation, if you buy his assumptions, means that you're going to have more chaos and more bloodshed, and probably more intervention by regional powers around Iraq like Saudi Arabia and Iran.
Dan Murphy is the Middle East correspondent for the Christian Science Monitor.
He joined us from Cairo.
Thanks, Dan.
My pleasure.
Forty years ago today, Neil Armstrong stepped down onto the surface of the moon as nearly everyone who could watch that amazing event on TV.
Most, of course, watched CBS that day to hear Walter Cronkite describe it.
As you've heard, the broadcaster famously known as the most trusted man in America died in New York this past Friday.
The U.S.
space program was just one of his great stories.
Before TV, Walter Cronkite covered D-Day.
He told us of the death of President Kennedy, defied one White House over the war in Vietnam and another over Watergate.
Yet, it's been almost 30 years since he left as the anchor of ""The CBS Evening News."" Those of us who remember Walter Cronkite need to tell those who don't what he did and why it was so important.
Our phone number is 800-989-8255; email: talk@npr.org.
And you can join the conversation on our Web site.
That's at npr.org, click on TALK OF THE NATION.
NPR news analyst Ted Koppel is still with us.
And, Ted, I don't think there's been anybody who's ever been graced with the word anchor who did not fear a little bit of that shadow of Walter Cronkite sitting over his shoulder.
Sure.

Because in point of fact, the term was coined by one of the CBS staff of senior producers or directors - it's not altogether clear who - who felt that in 1952, at the Democratic and Republican national conventions, there was this fellow sitting there, Walter Cronkite in this particular instance, who was sort of pulling it all together, holding it all in place, acting as the central clearinghouse for all these reports that were coming in from correspondents around the world, and they didn't have a name for that.
There had never been one of these guys before, at least not on television.
And someone came up with the term anchor, which, after all, is a device that keeps ships in place and provides a certain stability.
So, no, there will never quite be another Walter Cronkite.
And every subsequent anchor has always, I guess, felt or should have felt a certain indebtedness to Walter.
Forty years ago today, were you watching CBS News?
No.
And if I may, I will tell you why.
I was not watching ABC or NBC either.
I was a war correspondent in those days and I was in Cambodia.
The Cambodian war had - was underway and things were getting rather hectic over there.
Ron's political column, Watching Washington, runs every Monday, exclusively on our Web site, npr.org.
Thanks, Ron.
So Jernigan built a website called bestenglishname.com.
For about $2.50, people can take a quiz that uses an algorithm to generate five suitable names.
The site has drawn more than 2,000 customers.
Recently, Jernigan, who grew up in Memphis and London, showed me how it works.
We used my Mandarin name, Feiteng, which means fly swiftly upward, and answered questions by clicking on images on the screen.
Which sport would you like to play?
Let's say basketball.
I used to play a lot of basketball.
What style would you describe your style?
So we have Justin Bieber to choose - so who are we choosing from here?
This is a famous Korean star.
This is Brody Jenner.
He's sort of like a California boy.
OK.
Zac Efron, he's more, like, sporty.
(Laughter).
This guy's a little more rebellious.
Who is that?
Jay Chou, a Taiwanese singer and actor.
Lindsay keys in answers and voila - the computer kicks out choices for my new English name.
Drew.
Tate.
Julian.
Scott Kronick runs Ogilvy Public Relations in China and throughout Asia Pacific.
After more than two decades and thousands of Chinese staff, he's heard a lot of unconventional names.
We had a Popeye, and there's a Robin Hood.
Popeye"" was a very popular cartoon in China, but where do some of these other strange names come from?
Kronick wrote about it in his book, ""The Lighter Side Of China."" He thinks foreign teachers assigned some of these names to students as kind of a joke.
I think the English teachers that were here during the time were really having some fun.
I mean, I can't imagine where, you know - we have a staff member named Morphine - got his name.
Kronick's favorite name is this guy's.
My English name is Phat Song.
That's P-H-A-T, though Phat says his name also suits his build.
We chatted on Voice over Internet.
You don't see me.
I'm really fat (laughter).
F-A-T, yeah, I'm really F-A-T.
